The girl was recently diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. Fourteen students and three staff members were killed in the mass shooting at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Face-off by 2 rival YouTubers leads to mass brawl in Berlin
data.content: A face-off reportedly organised by two rival YouTubers- ThatsBekir and Bahar Al Amood, in the German capital Berlin led to a mass brawl. Around 400 people gathered at the Alexanderplatz square, with 50 of them hitting and attacking each other with pepper spray. Over 100 police officers deployed to contain the fight used tear gas to disperse the crowd.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Investigation on Russian meddling in 2016 US election concludes
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller has handed in the report on his nearly two-year investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 US presidential election. Mueller submitted the report to Attorney General William Barr who'll summarise it and decide how much to share with Congress. Mueller has charged 34 people, including US President Donald Trump's former aides as well as three companies.

"When Boeing supplies aircraft there are items mandatory for safety and then there are optional items," CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said. "The angle of attack indicator was on the optional list along with inflight entertainment system," he added.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Cruise ship stranded off Norway; 1,300 passengers being airlifted
data.content: Rescue helicopters have started airlifting 1,300 passengers and crew members from a cruise ship off the western coast of Norway. The Viking Sky cruise ship had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather". Built in 2017, the ship belongs to Viking Ocean Cruises, part of the Viking Cruises group founded by Norwegian billionaire Torstein Hagen.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: US man posed as Instagram star, spent $800 on Uber to assault teen
data.content: A Florida man has been accused of using Instagram to lure a 17-year-old girl, then sexually assaulting her. Richard Brown, 25, befriended her via Instagram, claiming to be 19 and an Instagram star. Brown reportedly paid over $800 for Uber rides that brought the girl across two states and finally to his home, where she was assaulted for three days.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: US disaster agency exposed private data of 23 lakh survivors
data.content: US Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) 'improperly' shared private data of around 23 lakh hurricane and wildfire survivors to an outside contractor. FEMA admitted the leak but said it found no evidence of the data being compromised. The data, including names, partial social security numbers and financial information, was provided while applying for transitional sheltering in hotels.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: 10 lakh people march in London demanding 2nd Brexit referendum
data.content: More than 10 lakh people marched through London on Saturday, demanding a second Brexit referendum, organisers of the 'Put It To The People' campaign said. It comes after the European Union agreed to delay Brexit until May 22 if the UK Parliament accepts Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal. The Parliament has rejected the Brexit deal twice.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Al-Qaeda-linked group attacks govt building in Somalia; 10 killed
data.content: At least 10 people were killed after al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabaab militants stormed a government building in Somalia's capital Mogadishu on Saturday. The militants entered after a suicide car bomb rammed into the building. Somalian security forces managed to secure the building following a gunfight, killing all four militants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 19-year-old US mass shooting survivor commits suicide year later
data.content: A 19-year-old girl who survived the mass shooting at a school in Parkland, US, last year has killed herself because of survivor's guilt, her family said. The girl was recently diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. Fourteen students and three staff members were killed in the mass shooting at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mossad spy who captured Nazi mastermind Eichmann dies aged 92
data.content: Rafi Eitan, a Mossad spy who led the Israeli team that captured Holocaust mastermind Adolf Eichmann in Argentina, has died at the age of 92. Eichmann was taken to Israel where he was tried and found guilty of crimes against humanity and subsequently hanged. Eitan was also involved in planning the attack on the Iraqi Osirak nuclear reactor in 1981.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Face-off by 2 rival YouTubers leads to mass brawl in Berlin
data.content: A face-off reportedly organised by two rival YouTubers- ThatsBekir and Bahar Al Amood, in the German capital Berlin led to a mass brawl. Around 400 people gathered at the Alexanderplatz square, with 50 of them hitting and attacking each other with pepper spray. Over 100 police officers deployed to contain the fight used tear gas to disperse the crowd.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 26 killed, 28 injured as bus catches fire in China
data.content: At least 26 people were killed and 28 others were injured after a bus caught fire in China's Hunan province on Friday, the local authorities said. There were 56 people on board the bus, including 53 passengers, two drivers and a tour guide. The two drivers were detained and an investigation was underway.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Investigation on Russian meddling in 2016 US election concludes
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller has handed in the report on his nearly two-year investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 US presidential election. Mueller submitted the report to Attorney General William Barr who'll summarise it and decide how much to share with Congress. Mueller has charged 34 people, including US President Donald Trump's former aides as well as three companies.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thailand goes to polls after five years of military rule
data.content: Polls opened in Thailand on Sunday for the first general election since the military ousted an elected government in a coup in 2014. About 51.4 million people are eligible to vote in the election which will appoint 500 members to the House of Representatives, the lower house of the Parliament. Preliminary unofficial results are expected to be announced today.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim's photographer fired for blocking crowd's view of him: Report
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's personal photographer has been fired for blocking Kim's neck from the crowd for around three seconds, a report said. The photographer also violated the rule of not taking pictures of Kim within a radius of two metres and a further rule that restricts photographers from taking pictures or video right in front of the leader.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Graeme Smith's parents among passengers airlifted from cruise ship
data.content: Ex-South Africa captain Graeme Smith's parents were among the passengers airlifted from a cruise ship that had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather" off the western coast of Norway. Smith thanked the cruise staff and rescue workers, and said that his parents were being assessed. The ship had 1,373 passengers and crew on board.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: NZ attack video not spotted on priority as suicide not reported: FB
data.content: Facebook said it is re-examining its live-stream policy after a terrorist live-streamed mass shootings on two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand. Facebook revealed its AI failed to detect the video, adding that live-streams are currently prioritised based on being flagged and when reported for showing suicide. The live-stream was watched around 200 times, but no user had reported it then.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Indian Navy rescues over 192 people in cyclone-hit Mozambique
data.content: The Indian Navy has rescued more than 192 people in the Cyclone Idai-hit Mozambique and provided assistance to 1,381 people in medical camps set up by it. India diverted three naval ships to the port city of Beira following a request from the government of Mozambique. India will send another ship loaded with relief materials to Mozambique.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Swaraj seeks report on abduction, conversion of 2 Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj has asked Indian High Commissioner in Pakistan to send a report on the abduction and conversion of two Hindu girls in Pakistan's Sindh province. This comes after a video of a father asking for the release of his two daughters surfaced on social media. The girls were reportedly kidnapped on the eve of Holi.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Guilty conscience: Swaraj to Pak Minister on abduction of Hindu girls
data.content: After Sushma Swaraj tweeted to Indian High Commission in Pakistan asking for report of two Hindu girls being allegedly abducted, Pakistan Minister Fawad Chaudhry tweeted it was Pakistan's internal issue. "It's not Modi's India where minorities are subjugated...it's Imran Khan's Naya Pak," he added. Swaraj said she had just asked for report and Fawad's response showed his "guilty conscience".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: France approaches EU to list Masood Azhar as terrorist
data.content: France has approached the European Union to designate Masood Azhar as a terrorist, the External Affairs Ministry said on Friday. It added, "The EU will take its decision once their process of designating a terrorist is complete." If the bloc lists Azhar as a terrorist, it will result in his travel ban and freezing of assets in all EU nations.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: New Zealand reopens mosques targeted in terror attack
data.content: The two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch city that were targeted in the terror attack earlier this month, were reopened to worshippers on Saturday. Small groups of worshippers were allowed back onto the grounds, while armed police patrolled the site. Fifty people were killed in shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Burj Khalifa lit up with NZ PM image, pays tribute to attack victims
data.content: The UAE on Friday projected New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern's image on the Burj Khalifa, the world's tallest structure in Dubai. The picture shows Ardern hugging a victim's family member. UAE Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum also thanked the New Zealand Prime Minister for the "sincere empathy" towards Muslims after the terror attack on mosques last week.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Asian homes targeted for gold robberies in UK: Report
data.content: Gold jewellery worth over £140 million was stolen in the UK from Asian families over the past five years, a Freedom of Information request by the BBC revealed. Nearly 28,000 thefts of 'Asian gold' have been recorded since 2013. It's the first time a comprehensive figure revealing the extent of thefts of 'Asian gold' in the UK has been collated.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Cruise ship stranded off Norway; 1,300 passengers being airlifted
data.content: Rescue helicopters have started airlifting 1,300 passengers and crew members from a cruise ship off the western coast of Norway. The Viking Sky cruise ship had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather". Built in 2017, the ship belongs to Viking Ocean Cruises, part of the Viking Cruises group founded by Norwegian billionaire Torstein Hagen.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Pak PM orders probe into abduction, conversion of 2 Hindu girls
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has ordered an investigation into the alleged abduction, forced conversion and marriages of two minor Hindu girls in Sindh province, Information Minister Chaudhry Fawad Hussain said. The girls were reportedly abducted from their home on the eve of Holi. The incident has triggered protests by the local Hindu community in Pakistan, seeking action against the perpetrators.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Italy to give citizenship to teen who saved 50 kids on hijacked bus
data.content: Italy will grant citizenship to a 13-year-old Egyptian boy who saved himself and 50 others abducted by their bus driver. Rami Shehata pretended to pray in Arabic while, in reality, he warned his father, who alerted police of the hijacking. He managed to hide his mobile phone when the driver insisted that all children hand over their phones to him.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Smuggled orangutan found inside passenger's luggage at Bali airport
data.content: A Russian man has been arrested in Bali on suspicion of trying to smuggle a young orangutan out of Indonesia. The two-year-old male orangutan, who was found in a suitcase at the airport, appeared to have been drugged, officials said. Two geckos and five lizards were also found in the Russian man's suitcase.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man posed as Instagram star, spent $800 on Uber to assault teen
data.content: A Florida man has been accused of using Instagram to lure a 17-year-old girl, then sexually assaulting her. Richard Brown, 25, befriended her via Instagram, claiming to be 19 and an Instagram star. Brown reportedly paid over $800 for Uber rides that brought the girl across two states and finally to his home, where she was assaulted for three days.

"The angle of attack indicator was on the optional list along with inflight entertainment system," he added.

data.title: 2 minor Hindu girls abducted on Holi eve in Pakistan
data.content: Two minor Hindu girls were allegedly abducted on Holi eve and forcibly converted to Islam in Pakistan's Sindh, a community leader said. The local media, however, reported that following the incident a video went viral in which the two girls said that they had converted to Islam willingly. The alleged abduction triggered protests by the local Hindu population.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump orders withdrawal of additional sanctions against N Korea
data.content: US President Donald Trump ordered the withdrawal of additional sanctions against North Korea, with officials saying he was referring to future sanctions. "President Trump likes Chairman Kim [Jong-un] and he doesn't think these sanctions will be necessary," the White House said. This comes after the Treasury Department imposed sanctions on two Chinese firms for illegally trading with North Korea.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.content: France has approached the European Union to designate Masood Azhar as a terrorist, the External Affairs Ministry said on Friday. It added, "The EU will take its decision once their process of designating a terrorist is complete." If the bloc lists Azhar as a terrorist, it will result in his travel ban and freezing of assets in all EU nations.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: US man posed as Instagram star, spent $800 on Uber to assault teen
data.content: A Florida man has been accused of using Instagram to lure a 17-year-old girl, then sexually assaulting her. Richard Brown, 25, befriended her via Instagram, claiming to be 19 and an Instagram star. Brown reportedly paid over $800 for Uber rides that brought the girl across two states and finally to his home, where she was assaulted for three days.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Burj Khalifa lit up with NZ PM image, pays tribute to attack victims
data.content: The UAE on Friday projected New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern's image on the Burj Khalifa, the world's tallest structure in Dubai. The picture shows Ardern hugging a victim's family member. UAE Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum also thanked the New Zealand Prime Minister for the "sincere empathy" towards Muslims after the terror attack on mosques last week.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Cruise ship stranded off Norway; 1,300 passengers being airlifted
data.content: Rescue helicopters have started airlifting 1,300 passengers and crew members from a cruise ship off the western coast of Norway. The Viking Sky cruise ship had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather". Built in 2017, the ship belongs to Viking Ocean Cruises, part of the Viking Cruises group founded by Norwegian billionaire Torstein Hagen.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Trump orders withdrawal of additional sanctions against N Korea
data.content: US President Donald Trump ordered the withdrawal of additional sanctions against North Korea, with officials saying he was referring to future sanctions. "President Trump likes Chairman Kim [Jong-un] and he doesn't think these sanctions will be necessary," the White House said. This comes after the Treasury Department imposed sanctions on two Chinese firms for illegally trading with North Korea.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New Zealand reopens mosques targeted in terror attack
data.content: The two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch city that were targeted in the terror attack earlier this month, were reopened to worshippers on Saturday. Small groups of worshippers were allowed back onto the grounds, while armed police patrolled the site. Fifty people were killed in shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Smuggled orangutan found inside passenger's luggage at Bali airport
data.content: A Russian man has been arrested in Bali on suspicion of trying to smuggle a young orangutan out of Indonesia. The two-year-old male orangutan, who was found in a suitcase at the airport, appeared to have been drugged, officials said. Two geckos and five lizards were also found in the Russian man's suitcase.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak PM orders probe into abduction, conversion of 2 Hindu girls
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has ordered an investigation into the alleged abduction, forced conversion and marriages of two minor Hindu girls in Sindh province, Information Minister Chaudhry Fawad Hussain said. The girls were reportedly abducted from their home on the eve of Holi. The incident has triggered protests by the local Hindu community in Pakistan, seeking action against the perpetrators.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 2 minor Hindu girls abducted on Holi eve in Pakistan
data.content: Two minor Hindu girls were allegedly abducted on Holi eve and forcibly converted to Islam in Pakistan's Sindh, a community leader said. The local media, however, reported that following the incident a video went viral in which the two girls said that they had converted to Islam willingly. The alleged abduction triggered protests by the local Hindu population.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Asian homes targeted for gold robberies in UK: Report
data.content: Gold jewellery worth over £140 million was stolen in the UK from Asian families over the past five years, a Freedom of Information request by the BBC revealed. Nearly 28,000 thefts of 'Asian gold' have been recorded since 2013. It's the first time a comprehensive figure revealing the extent of thefts of 'Asian gold' in the UK has been collated.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines defends its Boeing planes after crash
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines has rejected media reports that optional equipment for Boeing 737 MAX planes was critical for safety aboard the flight that crashed. "When Boeing supplies aircraft there are items mandatory for safety and then there are optional items," CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said. "The angle of attack indicator was on the optional list along with inflight entertainment system," he added.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Italy to give citizenship to teen who saved 50 kids on hijacked bus
data.content: Italy will grant citizenship to a 13-year-old Egyptian boy who saved himself and 50 others abducted by their bus driver. Rami Shehata pretended to pray in Arabic while, in reality, he warned his father, who alerted police of the hijacking. He managed to hide his mobile phone when the driver insisted that all children hand over their phones to him.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US disaster agency exposed private data of 23 lakh survivors
data.content: US Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) 'improperly' shared private data of around 23 lakh hurricane and wildfire survivors to an outside contractor. FEMA admitted the leak but said it found no evidence of the data being compromised. The data, including names, partial social security numbers and financial information, was provided while applying for transitional sheltering in hotels.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Investigation on Russian meddling in 2016 US election concludes
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller has handed in the report on his nearly two-year investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 US presidential election. Mueller submitted the report to Attorney General William Barr who'll summarise it and decide how much to share with Congress. Mueller has charged 34 people, including US President Donald Trump's former aides as well as three companies.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Thailand goes to polls after five years of military rule
data.content: Polls opened in Thailand on Sunday for the first general election since the military ousted an elected government in a coup in 2014. About 51.4 million people are eligible to vote in the election which will appoint 500 members to the House of Representatives, the lower house of the Parliament. Preliminary unofficial results are expected to be announced today.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 10 lakh people march in London demanding 2nd Brexit referendum
data.content: More than 10 lakh people marched through London on Saturday, demanding a second Brexit referendum, organisers of the 'Put It To The People' campaign said. It comes after the European Union agreed to delay Brexit until May 22 if the UK Parliament accepts Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal. The Parliament has rejected the Brexit deal twice.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Face-off by 2 rival YouTubers leads to mass brawl in Berlin
data.content: A face-off reportedly organised by two rival YouTubers- ThatsBekir and Bahar Al Amood, in the German capital Berlin led to a mass brawl. Around 400 people gathered at the Alexanderplatz square, with 50 of them hitting and attacking each other with pepper spray. Over 100 police officers deployed to contain the fight used tear gas to disperse the crowd.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim's photographer fired for blocking crowd's view of him: Report
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's personal photographer has been fired for blocking Kim's neck from the crowd for around three seconds, a report said. The photographer also violated the rule of not taking pictures of Kim within a radius of two metres and a further rule that restricts photographers from taking pictures or video right in front of the leader.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Al-Qaeda-linked group attacks govt building in Somalia; 10 killed
data.content: At least 10 people were killed after al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabaab militants stormed a government building in Somalia's capital Mogadishu on Saturday. The militants entered after a suicide car bomb rammed into the building. Somalian security forces managed to secure the building following a gunfight, killing all four militants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 19-year-old US mass shooting survivor commits suicide year later
data.content: A 19-year-old girl who survived the mass shooting at a school in Parkland, US, last year has killed herself because of survivor's guilt, her family said. The girl was recently diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. Fourteen students and three staff members were killed in the mass shooting at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 26 killed, 28 injured as bus catches fire in China
data.content: At least 26 people were killed and 28 others were injured after a bus caught fire in China's Hunan province on Friday, the local authorities said. There were 56 people on board the bus, including 53 passengers, two drivers and a tour guide. The two drivers were detained and an investigation was underway.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mossad spy who captured Nazi mastermind Eichmann dies aged 92
data.content: Rafi Eitan, a Mossad spy who led the Israeli team that captured Holocaust mastermind Adolf Eichmann in Argentina, has died at the age of 92. Eichmann was taken to Israel where he was tried and found guilty of crimes against humanity and subsequently hanged. Eitan was also involved in planning the attack on the Iraqi Osirak nuclear reactor in 1981.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Graeme Smith's parents among passengers airlifted from cruise ship
data.content: Ex-South Africa captain Graeme Smith's parents were among the passengers airlifted from a cruise ship that had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather" off the western coast of Norway. Smith thanked the cruise staff and rescue workers, and said that his parents were being assessed. The ship had 1,373 passengers and crew on board.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: NZ attack video not spotted on priority as suicide not reported: FB
data.content: Facebook said it is re-examining its live-stream policy after a terrorist live-streamed mass shootings on two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand. Facebook revealed its AI failed to detect the video, adding that live-streams are currently prioritised based on being flagged and when reported for showing suicide. The live-stream was watched around 200 times, but no user had reported it then.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Guilty conscience: Swaraj to Pak Minister on abduction of Hindu girls
data.content: After Sushma Swaraj tweeted to Indian High Commission in Pakistan asking for report of two Hindu girls being allegedly abducted, Pakistan Minister Fawad Chaudhry tweeted it was Pakistan's internal issue. "It's not Modi's India where minorities are subjugated...it's Imran Khan's Naya Pak," he added. Swaraj said she had just asked for report and Fawad's response showed his "guilty conscience".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Indian Navy rescues over 192 people in cyclone-hit Mozambique
data.content: The Indian Navy has rescued more than 192 people in the Cyclone Idai-hit Mozambique and provided assistance to 1,381 people in medical camps set up by it. India diverted three naval ships to the port city of Beira following a request from the government of Mozambique. India will send another ship loaded with relief materials to Mozambique.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: France approaches EU to list Masood Azhar as terrorist
data.content: France has approached the European Union to designate Masood Azhar as a terrorist, the External Affairs Ministry said on Friday. It added, "The EU will take its decision once their process of designating a terrorist is complete." If the bloc lists Azhar as a terrorist, it will result in his travel ban and freezing of assets in all EU nations.

data.content: At least 26 people were killed and 28 others were injured after a bus caught fire in China's Hunan province on Friday, the local authorities said. There were 56 people on board the bus, including 53 passengers, two drivers and a tour guide. The two drivers were detained and an investigation was underway.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Face-off by 2 rival YouTubers leads to mass brawl in Berlin
data.content: A face-off reportedly organised by two rival YouTubers- ThatsBekir and Bahar Al Amood, in the German capital Berlin led to a mass brawl. Around 400 people gathered at the Alexanderplatz square, with 50 of them hitting and attacking each other with pepper spray. Over 100 police officers deployed to contain the fight used tear gas to disperse the crowd.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Al-Qaeda-linked group attacks govt building in Somalia; 10 killed
data.content: At least 10 people were killed after al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabaab militants stormed a government building in Somalia's capital Mogadishu on Saturday. The militants entered after a suicide car bomb rammed into the building. Somalian security forces managed to secure the building following a gunfight, killing all four militants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Kim's photographer fired for blocking crowd's view of him: Report
data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's personal photographer has been fired for blocking Kim's neck from the crowd for around three seconds, a report said. The photographer also violated the rule of not taking pictures of Kim within a radius of two metres and a further rule that restricts photographers from taking pictures or video right in front of the leader.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Graeme Smith's parents among passengers airlifted from cruise ship
data.content: Ex-South Africa captain Graeme Smith's parents were among the passengers airlifted from a cruise ship that had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather" off the western coast of Norway. Smith thanked the cruise staff and rescue workers, and said that his parents were being assessed. The ship had 1,373 passengers and crew on board.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: NZ attack video not spotted on priority as suicide not reported: FB
data.content: Facebook said it is re-examining its live-stream policy after a terrorist live-streamed mass shootings on two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand. Facebook revealed its AI failed to detect the video, adding that live-streams are currently prioritised based on being flagged and when reported for showing suicide. The live-stream was watched around 200 times, but no user had reported it then.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Guilty conscience: Swaraj to Pak Minister on abduction of Hindu girls
data.content: After Sushma Swaraj tweeted to Indian High Commission in Pakistan asking for report of two Hindu girls being allegedly abducted, Pakistan Minister Fawad Chaudhry tweeted it was Pakistan's internal issue. "It's not Modi's India where minorities are subjugated...it's Imran Khan's Naya Pak," he added. Swaraj said she had just asked for report and Fawad's response showed his "guilty conscience".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Swaraj seeks report on abduction, conversion of 2 Hindu girls in Pak
data.content: External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj has asked Indian High Commissioner in Pakistan to send a report on the abduction and conversion of two Hindu girls in Pakistan's Sindh province. This comes after a video of a father asking for the release of his two daughters surfaced on social media. The girls were reportedly kidnapped on the eve of Holi.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Indian Navy rescues over 192 people in cyclone-hit Mozambique
data.content: The Indian Navy has rescued more than 192 people in the Cyclone Idai-hit Mozambique and provided assistance to 1,381 people in medical camps set up by it. India diverted three naval ships to the port city of Beira following a request from the government of Mozambique. India will send another ship loaded with relief materials to Mozambique.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: France approaches EU to list Masood Azhar as terrorist
data.content: France has approached the European Union to designate Masood Azhar as a terrorist, the External Affairs Ministry said on Friday. It added, "The EU will take its decision once their process of designating a terrorist is complete." If the bloc lists Azhar as a terrorist, it will result in his travel ban and freezing of assets in all EU nations.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Ethiopian Airlines defends its Boeing planes after crash
data.content: Ethiopian Airlines has rejected media reports that optional equipment for Boeing 737 MAX planes was critical for safety aboard the flight that crashed. "When Boeing supplies aircraft there are items mandatory for safety and then there are optional items," CEO Tewolde GebreMariam said. "The angle of attack indicator was on the optional list along with inflight entertainment system," he added.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Cruise ship stranded off Norway; 1,300 passengers being airlifted
data.content: Rescue helicopters have started airlifting 1,300 passengers and crew members from a cruise ship off the western coast of Norway. The Viking Sky cruise ship had sent out a mayday signal due to "engine problems in bad weather". Built in 2017, the ship belongs to Viking Ocean Cruises, part of the Viking Cruises group founded by Norwegian billionaire Torstein Hagen.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: Trump orders withdrawal of additional sanctions against N Korea
data.content: US President Donald Trump ordered the withdrawal of additional sanctions against North Korea, with officials saying he was referring to future sanctions. "President Trump likes Chairman Kim [Jong-un] and he doesn't think these sanctions will be necessary," the White House said. This comes after the Treasury Department imposed sanctions on two Chinese firms for illegally trading with North Korea.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man posed as Instagram star, spent $800 on Uber to assault teen
data.content: A Florida man has been accused of using Instagram to lure a 17-year-old girl, then sexually assaulting her. Richard Brown, 25, befriended her via Instagram, claiming to be 19 and an Instagram star. Brown reportedly paid over $800 for Uber rides that brought the girl across two states and finally to his home, where she was assaulted for three days.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Italy to give citizenship to teen who saved 50 kids on hijacked bus
data.content: Italy will grant citizenship to a 13-year-old Egyptian boy who saved himself and 50 others abducted by their bus driver. Rami Shehata pretended to pray in Arabic while, in reality, he warned his father, who alerted police of the hijacking. He managed to hide his mobile phone when the driver insisted that all children hand over their phones to him.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Burj Khalifa lit up with NZ PM image, pays tribute to attack victims
data.content: The UAE on Friday projected New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern's image on the Burj Khalifa, the world's tallest structure in Dubai. The picture shows Ardern hugging a victim's family member. UAE Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum also thanked the New Zealand Prime Minister for the "sincere empathy" towards Muslims after the terror attack on mosques last week.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: New Zealand reopens mosques targeted in terror attack
data.content: The two mosques in New Zealand's Christchurch city that were targeted in the terror attack earlier this month, were reopened to worshippers on Saturday. Small groups of worshippers were allowed back onto the grounds, while armed police patrolled the site. Fifty people were killed in shootings at the two mosques.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pak PM orders probe into abduction, conversion of 2 Hindu girls
data.content: Pakistan PM Imran Khan has ordered an investigation into the alleged abduction, forced conversion and marriages of two minor Hindu girls in Sindh province, Information Minister Chaudhry Fawad Hussain said. The girls were reportedly abducted from their home on the eve of Holi. The incident has triggered protests by the local Hindu community in Pakistan, seeking action against the perpetrators.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 2 minor Hindu girls abducted on Holi eve in Pakistan
data.content: Two minor Hindu girls were allegedly abducted on Holi eve and forcibly converted to Islam in Pakistan's Sindh, a community leader said. The local media, however, reported that following the incident a video went viral in which the two girls said that they had converted to Islam willingly. The alleged abduction triggered protests by the local Hindu population.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Asian homes targeted for gold robberies in UK: Report
data.content: Gold jewellery worth over £140 million was stolen in the UK from Asian families over the past five years, a Freedom of Information request by the BBC revealed. Nearly 28,000 thefts of 'Asian gold' have been recorded since 2013. It's the first time a comprehensive figure revealing the extent of thefts of 'Asian gold' in the UK has been collated.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Smuggled orangutan found inside passenger's luggage at Bali airport
data.content: A Russian man has been arrested in Bali on suspicion of trying to smuggle a young orangutan out of Indonesia. The two-year-old male orangutan, who was found in a suitcase at the airport, appeared to have been drugged, officials said. Two geckos and five lizards were also found in the Russian man's suitcase.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US disaster agency exposed private data of 23 lakh survivors
data.content: US Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) 'improperly' shared private data of around 23 lakh hurricane and wildfire survivors to an outside contractor. FEMA admitted the leak but said it found no evidence of the data being compromised. The data, including names, partial social security numbers and financial information, was provided while applying for transitional sheltering in hotels.
data.author: Kanishka Pandey

data.title: Face-off by 2 rival YouTubers leads to mass brawl in Berlin
data.content: A face-off reportedly organised by two rival YouTubers- ThatsBekir and Bahar Al Amood, in the German capital Berlin led to a mass brawl. Around 400 people gathered at the Alexanderplatz square, with 50 of them hitting and attacking each other with pepper spray. Over 100 police officers deployed to contain the fight used tear gas to disperse the crowd.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 10 lakh people march in London demanding 2nd Brexit referendum
data.content: More than 10 lakh people marched through London on Saturday, demanding a second Brexit referendum, organisers of the 'Put It To The People' campaign said. It comes after the European Union agreed to delay Brexit until May 22 if the UK Parliament accepts Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal. The Parliament has rejected the Brexit deal twice.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Al-Qaeda-linked group attacks govt building in Somalia; 10 killed
data.content: At least 10 people were killed after al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabaab militants stormed a government building in Somalia's capital Mogadishu on Saturday. The militants entered after a suicide car bomb rammed into the building. Somalian security forces managed to secure the building following a gunfight, killing all four militants.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 19-year-old US mass shooting survivor commits suicide year later
data.content: A 19-year-old girl who survived the mass shooting at a school in Parkland, US, last year has killed herself because of survivor's guilt, her family said. The girl was recently diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. Fourteen students and three staff members were killed in the mass shooting at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 26 killed, 28 injured as bus catches fire in China
data.content: At least 26 people were killed and 28 others were injured after a bus caught fire in China's Hunan province on Friday, the local authorities said. There were 56 people on board the bus, including 53 passengers, two drivers and a tour guide. The two drivers were detained and an investigation was underway.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Investigation on Russian meddling in 2016 US election concludes
data.content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller has handed in the report on his nearly two-year investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 US presidential election. Mueller submitted the report to Attorney General William Barr who'll summarise it and decide how much to share with Congress. Mueller has charged 34 people, including US President Donald Trump's former aides as well as three companies.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Mossad spy who captured Nazi mastermind Eichmann dies aged 92
data.content: Rafi Eitan, a Mossad spy who led the Israeli team that captured Holocaust mastermind Adolf Eichmann in Argentina, has died at the age of 92. Eichmann was taken to Israel where he was tried and found guilty of crimes against humanity and subsequently hanged. Eitan was also involved in planning the attack on the Iraqi Osirak nuclear reactor in 1981.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.content: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's personal photographer has been fired for blocking Kim's neck from the crowd for around three seconds, a report said. data.title: Thailand goes to polls after five years of military rule
data.content: Polls opened in Thailand on Sunday for the first general election since the military ousted an elected government in a coup in 2014. About 51.4 million people are eligible to vote in the election which will appoint 500 members to the House of Representatives, the lower house of the Parliament. Preliminary unofficial results are expected to be announced today.
data.author: Nandini Sinha
